contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "fear" and "terror" mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the fear is intense. Alternate translation: "put a terrible fear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: put the fear and terror

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that they are to obey them. Alternate translation: "obey them carefully" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: keep them and do them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "detest" and "abhor" mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of hatred. Alternate translation: "You will completely hate" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: You will utterly detest and abhor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Moses repeats the same command both positively and negatively to emphasize the importance of remembering. The command is plural. Alternate translation: "Be careful to remember" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.glQuote: Remember and do not forget

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of Yahweh's power that he used to rescue his people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: by your great strength and by the display of your power

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "fear" and "terror" mean the same thing and emphasize the intensity of fear. Alternate translation: "a terrible fear of you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: the fear of you and the terror of you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "good" and "right" have similar meanings and emphasize the importance of right behavior. Alternate translation: "when you do what is right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: when you do what is good and right

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words have similar meanings and refer to various miracles. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: a sign or a wonder

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these phrases mean basically the same thing. Moses is emphasizing that they must carefully find out what truly happened at the city. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: examine the evidence, make search, and investigate it thoroughly

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "neighbor" and "brother" share similar meanings and emphasize the close relationship that they have with their fellow Israelites. Alternate translation: "his fellow Israelite" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: his neighbor or his brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "needy" and "poor" mean basically the same thing and emphasize that these are people who cannot help themselves. Alternate translation: "help your fellow Israelites who cannot help themselves" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: your brother, to your needy, and to your poor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases mean the same thing. They both refer to a person who is not an Israelite. Yahweh is emphasizing that the people of Israel should not let a foreigner rule over them. Alternate translation: "a foreigner over yourself" or "a non-Israelite over yourself" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: a foreigner, who is not your brother, over yourself

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these words mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: "afraid to fight in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: fearful or fainthearted

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "takes a wife" and "marries her" mean the same thing. Alternate translation: "When a man marries a woman" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: When a man takes a wife and marries her

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words have similar meanings and emphasize that this is a person who cannot help himself. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: poor and needy

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words have similar meanings and emphasize how tired the people were. Alternate translation: "tired and exhausted" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: faint and weary

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words mean basically the same thing. They emphasize that Israel became a large and powerful nation. Alternate translation: "very great" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: a great, mighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases say basically the same thing. They emphasize that the Egyptians acted very harshly. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: treated us badly and afflicted us

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Alternate translation: "from heaven, your holy dwelling place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: from the holy place where you live, from heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: This doublet is three ways of saying that Yahweh will make the Israelites' animals many and strong. Alternate translation: "all of your animals along with the calves of the cattle and the lambs of the flocks" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: the fruit of your beasts, the increase of your cattle, and the young of your flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: This doublet is two ways of saying that Yahweh will make the Israelites' animals many and strong. Alternate translation: "the calves of the cattle and the lambs of the flocks" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: the increase of your cattle, and the young of your flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "oppressed" and "crushed" mean basically the same thing. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "they will always oppress and crush you" or "they will oppress you continually" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: you will always be oppressed and crushed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words "proverb" and "byword" mean basically the same thing. This can be translated as a new sentence. Alternate translation: "of horror. The people, in the places where Yahweh will send you, will make up proverbs and bywords about you" or "of horror. Yahweh will send you to peoples who will laugh at you and ridicule you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: of horror, a proverb, and a byword, among all the peoples where Yahweh will lead you away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "commandments" and "regulations" are a doublet for "all that Yahweh has commanded you to do." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: his commandments and his regulations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "joyfulness" and "gladness of heart" mean the same thing. They emphasize that the people should have been very glad to worship Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: joyfulness and gladness of heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that the enemy will come from a nation that is very far away from Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: from far away, from the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "signs" and "wonders" both refer to the plagues that Yahweh had sent upon Egypt. Alternate translation: "and all of the powerful things that Yahweh did" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: the signs, and those great wonders

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "anger" and "wrath" and "fury" mean basically the same thing and emphasize the great intensity of Yahweh's anger. Alternate translation: "in extremely great anger" or "because he was extremely angry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: in anger, in wrath, and in great fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases have the same meaning and are metonyms for Yahweh, emphasizing that he is the one who gives life and determines the length of people's lifetimes. Alternate translation: "Yahweh is the only one who can enable you to live a long life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: For he is your life and the length of your days

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh is fair and does what is right. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: He is just and upright

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "perverted" and "crooked" mean basically the same thing. Moses uses them to emphasize how wicked the generation is. Alternate translation: "a completely wicked generation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: a perverted and crooked generation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "foolish" and "senseless" mean the same thing and emphasize how foolish the people are for disobeying Yahweh. Alternate translation: "you extremely foolish people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: you foolish and senseless people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "vengeance" and "recompense" mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: "I will have vengeance and punish Israel's enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: Vengeance is mine to give, and recompense

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words both mean to watch over and to protect. They are often metaphors for "obeyed," but here they should be translated literally because they refer to a time when the Levites literally killed people who were rebelling against Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: guarded ... kept
